abstracts.cdata!:
Ratings for the Integrated Human Development Project for Maldives were as follows: outcomes were moderately unsatisfactory, the risk to development outcome was moderate, the Bank performance was moderately unsatisfactory, and the Borrower performance was also moderately unsatisfactory. Some lessons learned included: the most effective way to improve services in island economies is to develop ownership and accountability at the community level. Procurement training and capacity building for implementing agencies would need to pay more attention to the contract management aspects of procurement. All actors, including Ministries of Finance, need to be on board to successfully manage contracts. Projects should not rely extensively on human resources that are to be trained during the project for purposes of project implementation. Where staff of implementing agencies needs to be trained, on-the job training with the help of consultant trainers may work better than deputing a large number of staff frequently or on long training programs during the project period. Further, genuine decentralization or transfer of authority with accountability is required to effectively address the issue of ownership by subordinate implementing agencies. An important corollary is that small or medium size civil works located on remote islands should be managed and supervised by island level leadership or management. Island communities have successfully managed a wide variety of civil works, can provide close supervision, direct small but important design changes and ensure the accountability of the contractor. For large works, a tandem arrangement, with
initial design and bidding responsibilities at the central level, but supervision and payment authorization at the island level, may work better than management through an external contractor, who has no accountability at the island level. The lack of authority at the local level also meant that the islands looked to the center to fix even the smallest of problems and repairs.

repnme.cdata!:
Maldives - Proposal to restructure the
            integrated human development project

abstracts.cdata!:
This project paper seeks the approval of
            the Executive Director to introduce changes in the Maldives
            Integrated Human Development Project (Credit No. 3948,
            Project ID P078523). The proposed restructuring involves
            changing the project objectives so that they are measurable
            in line with the requirements of IDA 14. The proposed
            changes will not affect the project components nor the
            activities financed by the project. The changes also better
            reflect the evolving situation in the Maldives which was hit
            by the Tsunami on December 26,2004. The new objectives of
            the project are to assist the borrower in improving the
            delivery of social services on Focus Islands. Two of the
            eight performance indicators will be dropped because it is
            difficult to establish a baseline for these and thus they
            are not in line with the IDA 14 guidelines. The proposed
            changes will have little effect on the project as appraised.
            The one activity that has been dropped will be a
            contribution to an UNDP supported micro-finance program,

5265209.majtheme: Social protection and risk management,Rural development,Human development

abstracts.cdata!:
The Maldives Integrated Human
            Development Project aims to: (a) improve social outcomes and
            promote economic growth by strengthening social services
            delivery (education, health and nutrition services) for the
            population; (b) reduce poverty and promote regional equity
            by strengthening social service delivery and increasing
            economic opportunities in atolls remote from the prosperous
            Male region; and (c) promote ecologically sustainable
            development by concentrating services and populations on
            ecologically viable islands within these atolls. There are
            four project components along with project management and
            evaluation. Component 1 strengthens education service
            delivery. This project component will support: (a) enhancing
            cost-effective access to secondary education, (b) improving
            the quality of education on focus islands, and (c)
            conducting whole school evaluations including assessments.
            Component 2 strengthens health service delivery. The project
            component supports (a) rationalizing care for
            non-communicable diseases (NCDs), (b) enhancing support for
            nutrition promotion to address the widespread problem of
            childhood malnutrition through communication of strategic
            behavioral changes, improved nutrition surveillance, and
            greater use of locally relevant complementary foods.
            Component 3 strengthens employment services. It will enhance
            employment prospects of individuals, particularly those
            residing in remote atolls by (a) supporting cost effective
            job information and job counseling services through a
            national jobs information network, job centers on focus
            islands, career and employment counseling through job
            centers and business centers to facilitate business
            development; and (b) expanding existing mircrofinance
            programs. Component 4 strengthens community services. The
            project will improve service delivery by strengthening
            community services. Component 5 supports the project
            monitoring and evaluation framework.

repnme.cdata!:
Maldives - Integrated Human Development
            Project : environmental management

abstracts.cdata!:
The project development objectives are
            to improve social services, contain the rise in public
            services unit costs, and promote economic opportunities on
            selected, ecologically viable focus islands in four atolls.
            The focus island development strategy is part of a new
            Government strategy to improve the quality and
            cost-effectiveness of service delivery outside of the Male
            region, focusing investments on islands which are
            ecologically sustainable and can, in the long run, develop
            into centers offering an alternative to the capital region
            for access to services,  and economic opportunities. The
            Project does not require a full environmental assessment,
            given the nature and scale of project activities, and, it is
            classified as a category B. Screening and assessment show
            these activities are likely to have minimal adverse
            environmental impacts, and, would not involve conversion, or
            degradation of critical natural habitats, or other natural
            habitats nor cultural property. However, some activities
            may, unless careful project design and implementation is
            undertaken, potentially have specific impacts of low
            significance. These are site specific impacts due to
            construction waste; improper disposal of health care waste;
            and, improper solid waste and sewerage disposal. Mitigation
            measures should minimize identified potential impacts
            through: due care of site selection, taking into account the
            fragile and vulnerable island ecosystems, including
            groundwater hydrology, coral reefs, and enclosed lagoons.
            Moreover, potential impacts on threatened or endangered
            species should be mitigated; and, dewatering activities
            should be implemented in accordance to the Water Authority
            regulations, while liquid effluents must be discharges via
            maritime outfalls. Discharge points shall be established
            through wastewater discharge permits  granted by the
            relevant authorities. Each health care facility must
            establish a Health Care Waste Management Plan, appropriate
            to the scale and type of activities, and identified hazards.
